id480395.page:
Welcome

When asked to reflect on her own experiences as a political prisoner in relationship to her work as a “prison abolitionist” with Critical Resistance, Angela Davis comments, “The most important lessons emanating from those campaigns, we thought, demonstrate the need to examine the overall role of the prison system, especially its class and racial character. There was a relationship, as George Jackson had insisted, between the rising numbers of political prisoners, and the imprisonment of increasing numbers of poor people of color. If prison was the state-sanctioned destination for activists such as myself, it was also used as a surrogate solution to social problems associated with poverty and racism.” While speaking very directly to the prison system, her critical connections on an institution we commonly accept as a logical destination for those deemed as “criminal” offers a guiding framework for our survey course on “racial and ethnic groups in the United States.” As we think comparatively about the experiences of racial and ethnic groups, through themes relevant to the historical development of America (settler colonialism, slavery, immigration, labor, politics, community formation...) we seek to ask the type of questions demonstrated by Davis in her reflections on the prison in U.S. society. Instead of simply accepting institutions and ideologies as given, or the only ways to do things, the driving question of a course like ours is how can we learn from the movements that created Ethnic Studies (liberation movements of the 1960s) and envision a different reality.

Class Description

This course provides students with the tools and historical background needed to engage in meaningful and informed debates about race, gender, legal status, crime and punishment. Central to this learning and analysis is the question, ‘how might we forge an abolition pedagogy’, and how has/can such pedagogy be formed in antiracist and feminist scholarship, grounded in domestic and transnational grassroots social movements? In addressing these, the course intimately links the community and the academy as sites of organizing and analysis in critical prison studies and abolition movements through a comparative racial- ethnic analysis.

Student Learning/Course Goals

Students will develop critical thinking skills.

Will be able to organize and communicate efficiently the complicated historical and theoretical arrangements of critical prison studies.

Will be able to demonstrate their understanding of Ethnic Studies themes and perspectives.

Analyze how politics of coalition have been formed across race, gender, and legal status.

Understand how to compose critical pedagogical methodologies, which are ‘abolitionist’ in position and praxis.

To build a collective library of material that allows us to consider the possibilities of ‘abolition pedagogy’ in social movement struggles.

This course will empower students with knowledge and skills that will enhance their ability to communicate across lines of race, gender, and ethnicity in a diverse society. But more than that, a multicultural society is bound from time to time to throw up issues that divide and appear irresoluble. Given the tools of our discourse, we will be prepared to create critical acceptance and deep respect for the principle of equity and difference. Our dialogue will be open and equal.

This course will embrace intellectual advocacy and seek to create an ‘active and reflective space’. This requires that all members of this class be contributors to the ongoing discussions of some of the most exciting, and also contentious questions of the contemporary United States of America.


Image license: Creative Commons. Source: http://www.flickr.com/photos/shankbone/6183258235/

id4126813.page:
Course Info

Format: Three hours of lecture and one hour of discussion per week
Units: 4

Prerequisites: None


Semesters Offered: Spring

Grading:


Class Schedule

Lecture Schedule: Tu Thu 9:30 - 11:00am
Location: 160 Kroeber Hall
Final Exam: Group 10: Wednesday, May 9, 2012   11:30am - 2:30pm


Course Catalog Description

This survey course will examine the historical experiences of European immigrants, African Americans, and Latinos, emphasizing the themes of migration and economic change since the late 19th century. Though the class will focus on the three groups, the course will also address salient features of the experiences of Asian Americans, Native Americans, and recently arrived immigrants in light of the themes of the course. Intragroup differences such as class and gender will be discussed.

id1496710.page:
Class Policies

In this section:

  • Course Content
  • General Information
  • Accommodations for students with disabilities
  • General Information
  • Paper Policy
  • Academic honesty
  • Laptops

Course Content

Issues of race, gender, sexuality and legal status are specifically dealt with as they relate to the criminal justice system, histories of criminalization and social movements to reform/abolish the current criminal justice system. Please note that some of these readings contain experiences of sexual and racial violence, which you might find disturbing. If students are uncomfortable with readings or discussion, please inform the instructor who will provide support and information on counseling services.

General Information

There are many ways in which to understand and examine the course material. As such, it is vital that we continuously maintain a level of respect for our peers in our verbal communication, listening and body language. Critical discussion is a group activity. We will regularly disagree, but respectfully.

The course format consists of lectures, videos, and discussions. You are expected to attend all class sessions, to complete the assigned readings as scheduled, and to participate in discussions. Generally I will attempt to reserve time during class to discuss the assigned readings, but special attention will be devoted to discussion during sections. You are responsible for making sure that the contact information the instructor and GSI have for you is correct and current. You may miss vital class information if you do not ensure this.

Attendance and In-Class Participation

Students are expected to come to class on time, with the reading of assigned texts for that week already completed. You should be prepared to be engaged in class dialogues and contribute your own informed analysis (please note that this is more than opinion). In addition, students will be asked to periodically respond to short in-class assignments based on a posted b-space reading. Students should always bring the article/reading to class.

Grade weight: 20%

Accommodations for students with disabilities

If you have a disability that you feel will affect your work in this class, if you have emergency medical information that you want to tell me, or if you need special arrangements in case of an emergency or evacuation, please let me know about it as soon as possible. Before I can make disability-related accommodations for you in your coursework, I will need a letter from the Disabled Students Program (http://dsp.berkeley.edu) detailing the accommodations that you need.

Paper Policy

Absence is not an acceptable reason to turn in any assignments after the due date. Papers may only be submitted late with the instructorʼs previous approval. In order to obtain the instructors approval, you must contact the instructor no later than 24 hours before the assignment is due. Should a person hand in a late paper without previous approval, the paper will be graded but the grade will be reduced a third of a grade for each calendar date late. For example, a paper that is two days late and earns an A- will receive a grade of B.

Academic honesty

Plagiarism, cheating, and other forms of academic dishonesty will not be tolerated. Plagiarism involves presenting other peoples ideas as your own, without citing the appropriate source. Please review the university policy on academic honesty: http://students.berkeley.edu/osl/sja.asp?id=983&rcol=1202

If you have any questions about this policy, or about how to avoid academic dishonesty, please email me or see me in office hours.

Laptops

If you plan to use a laptop or other technical device designed to assist you in the classroom, please contact the instructor within the first week of class to discuss classroom technical-device policies.


University Policies

http://catalog.berkeley.edu/policies/
